Award.AwardTitle: Physical Processes Governing Energy and Momentum Flows on Multiple Scales in Near-Earth Space Using a First-principles-based Data Assimilation System (DAS) for the Global Ionospher
Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant is for partial support of a project selected and funded under the 2012 NASA-NSF partnership for Space Weather Modeling Collaborations. It is a collaborative effort, led by Utah State University and with participation also from University of Southern California and NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory. The objective is to first combine multiple existing first principles ionospheric data assimilation models to develop a modular Data Assimilation System (DAS) capable of modeling the global Ionosphere-Thermosphere-Electrodynamics (ITE). Next, a Multi-model Ensemble Prediction System (MEPS) will be constructed for modeling the I-T-E system that incorporates the existing data assimilation models with different physics, numerics, and initial conditions. MEPS will allow ensemble modeling with different data assimilation models for specific science studies and applications. MEPS will be modular so that it can be coupled to lower atmosphere (weather) models and to first-principles-based magnetosphere models. Hence, MEPS can take account of upward propagating tides, planetary waves, and gravity waves. Since MEPS reconstructions will be consistent with the available I-T-E measurements, self-consistent ion outflows, convection E-fields, precipitation, currents, etc., can be provided to magnetosphere models for inputs and/or validation. The modular architecture also means that data assimilation models (ionosphere, thermosphere, electrodynamics) developed by others can be easily incorporated in MEPS. In addition, MEPS will include different data assimilation models for specific parts of the near-Earth space domain, which will allow ensemble modeling of specific events with several different data assimilation models. The MEPS data assimilation models will be made available to the scientific community so that others can study the I-T-E system with state-of-the-art data assimilation models. The use of these models will lead to a paradigm shift in how basic physical processes are studied in near-Earth space.

When completed, the MEPS model (with component data assimilation models; ionosphere, ionosphere-plasmasphere, thermosphere, high-latitude ionosphere-electrodynamics, and mid-low latitude ionosphere-electrodynamics) will be delivered to the Community Coordinated Modeling Center (CCMC) for access by the scientific community and eventual transition to use for operational space weather forecasting. The results of this effort will help provide a several hour predictive capability for the ITE that is a high priority national space weather need. Graduate students at USU will participate in the project

POR.DRECONTENT:
The lower atmosphere of the Earth is frequently subjected to severe weather, including tornados, hurricanes, rain storms, blizzards, and intense winds. During the last five decades, the meteorologists have shown that the best way to specify and forecast severe weather is with the use of an ensemble of physics-based data assimilation models. Like the lower atmosphere, the Earth upper atmosphere/ionosphere also experiences severe space weather disturbances, particularly during geomagnetic storms, including storm enhanced density ridges, propagating density patches, auroral arcs, wind surges in narrow channels, and turbulence that leads to upward drifting bubbles (Figure 1). Unfortunately, the space weather disturbances can have detrimental effects on human systems and operations. They can adversely affect over-the-horizon radars, High Frequency (HF) communications, surveillance, power grids, pipelines, the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) Wide-Area Augmentation System (WAAS), and survey and navigation systems that use Global Positioning System (GPS) satellites.

Like the meteorologists, the primary goal of our 5-year involvement in the NASA/NSF Space Weather Modeling Collaboration program was to create a Multimodel Ensemble Prediction System (MEPS), which will allow ensemble modeling of the upper atmosphere/ionosphere with different data assimilation models that are based on different physical assumptions, assimilation techniques, and initial conditions. The MEPS ensemble contains seven different data assimilation models. The models are capable of assimilating data from a variety of data sources, including in situ electron densities from satellites, electron density profiles from radars, Total Electron Content (TEC) measurements between ground receivers and the GPS satellites, occultation data from satellite constellations, and ultraviolet (UV) emissions measured by satellites (Figure 2).

In one study, we used our MEPS models to elucidate the similarities and differences in the individual data assimilation model reconstructions of the mid-low latitude ionosphere when the same data were assimilated. Ensemble model averages were also obtained. For this ensemble modeling study, we selected the quiet/storm period of 16 to 17 March 2013 (equinox, solar medium). Six models were used to produce an ensemble average output for the vertical Total Electron Content of the ionosphere for latitudes less than 60˚ and all longitudes. The data assimilated included GPS TEC and occultation data from a constellation of satellites. Both a simple average and a weighted average of the models were used in the ensemble averaging in order to determine if there was an improvement of the ensemble averages over the individual models. For this quiet/storm period the ensemble average of the six models was better than the individual models (Figure 3).

The MEPS models will be available to scientists, engineers and students via the Community Coordinated Modeling Center (CCMC) located at the NASA Goddard Space Flight Center. The application of ensemble modeling with several different data assimilation models will lead to a paradigm shift in how basic physical processes are studied in near-Earth space, and it is expected to lead to a significant advance in space weather specifications and forecasting.

The research was accomplished by a team of scientists from Utah State University, University of Southern California, and the Jet Propulsion Laboratory.
